backgroundSteps.text: Before databases had transactions, a power failure during a bank transfer could leave money in limbo — deducted from one account but never credited to another. Data inconsistency was the norm.
backgroundSteps.title: The Corruption Problem

backgroundSteps.text: Jim Gray at IBM tackled this chaos in the 1970s. His insight: group related operations together and guarantee they either all succeed or all fail. No partial states allowed.
backgroundSteps.title: Gray's Breakthrough

backgroundSteps.text: The ACID properties emerged as the gold standard for reliable data operations. They transformed databases from fragile systems into ones businesses could trust with critical data.
backgroundSteps.title: The ACID Standard

examplesSteps.text: Banking transfers are the classic example. Moving $100 from savings to checking must debit one and credit the other atomically — or neither should happen.
examplesSteps.title: Banking Transfers

examplesSteps.text: E-commerce checkout involves inventory reduction, payment processing, and order creation. All must succeed together, or the customer gets charged without receiving their product.
examplesSteps.title: E-commerce Orders

examplesSteps.text: Airline booking systems face extreme concurrency — thousands of users trying to book the same seats. Transactions prevent double-booking while maintaining performance.
examplesSteps.title: Airline Reservations

examplesSteps.text: Social media platforms use transactions for complex operations like posting a photo with tags, location, and notifications — all must be recorded consistently.
examplesSteps.title: Social Media Posts

explanationSteps.text: Atomicity means 'all or nothing.' A transaction either completes entirely or has no effect at all. There's no partial completion — if any part fails, everything rolls back.
explanationSteps.title: Atomicity

explanationSteps.text: Consistency ensures transactions bring the database from one valid state to another. Rules defined in the schema (like account balance >= 0) are never violated.
explanationSteps.title: Consistency

explanationSteps.text: Isolation means concurrent transactions don't interfere with each other. Each transaction sees a consistent snapshot, as if it were running alone.
explanationSteps.title: Isolation

explanationSteps.text: Durability guarantees that once a transaction commits, its changes survive system crashes. The database uses write-ahead logging to ensure committed data isn't lost.
explanationSteps.title: Durability

explanationSteps.text: Isolation levels trade off between consistency and performance. Serializable is safest but slowest; Read Committed is faster but allows some anomalies.
explanationSteps.title: Isolation Levels

userInput.lessonDescription: Understanding database transactions and ACID properties for maintaining data integrity in concurrent systems

mechanicsSteps.text: A transaction begins with BEGIN, then executes statements. Changes are held in a buffer, invisible to other transactions until COMMIT makes them permanent.
mechanicsSteps.title: Transaction Lifecycle

mechanicsSteps.text: Write-ahead logging records changes before applying them. If a crash occurs mid-transaction, the log allows the database to either complete or undo the changes during recovery.
mechanicsSteps.title: Write-Ahead Logging

mechanicsSteps.text: Locks prevent concurrent access conflicts. When a transaction modifies a row, it acquires an exclusive lock. Other transactions must wait until the lock releases.
mechanicsSteps.title: Locking Mechanisms

mechanicsSteps.text: Deadlocks occur when two transactions each hold a lock the other needs. The database detects this circular wait and aborts one transaction to break the cycle.
mechanicsSteps.title: Deadlock Detection

mechanicsSteps.text: ROLLBACK undoes all changes made during the transaction. The database uses the log to reverse each operation in the opposite order it was applied.
mechanicsSteps.title: Rollback Process

backgroundSteps.text: Why do seniors get discounts while business travelers pay premium? Why does software cost different amounts in different countries? Economists discovered the logic behind seemingly arbitrary pricing.
backgroundSteps.title: The Pricing Puzzle

backgroundSteps.text: Arthur Pigou formalized price discrimination theory in the 1920s. He showed that charging different prices to different customers could actually be economically efficient under certain conditions.
backgroundSteps.title: Pigou's Insight

backgroundSteps.text: The rise of big data transformed price discrimination from crude segmentation to personalized pricing. Every click, purchase, and search helps companies estimate your willingness to pay.
backgroundSteps.title: The Data Revolution

examplesSteps.text: Airlines are masters of price discrimination. The same seat costs $200 or $2000 depending on when you book, whether you stay Saturday, and if you're flying for business or leisure.
examplesSteps.title: Airline Pricing

examplesSteps.text: Movie theaters charge different prices for matinees, seniors, and students. They're segmenting customers by time flexibility and price sensitivity.
examplesSteps.title: Movie Tickets

examplesSteps.text: Academic software discounts are dramatic — students might pay $50 for software that costs businesses $500. The assumption: students can't afford full price but will become paying customers later.
examplesSteps.title: Educational Discounts

examplesSteps.text: Happy hour pricing segments customers by time availability. Those who can drink at 4pm are often more price-sensitive than the 8pm crowd willing to pay full price.
examplesSteps.title: Happy Hour Economics

explanationSteps.text: Price discrimination means charging different prices for the same product to different customers. It's not about cost differences — it's about extracting more consumer surplus.
explanationSteps.title: Definition

explanationSteps.text: First-degree discrimination charges each customer their maximum willingness to pay. It's theoretically perfect but practically impossible without mind-reading. Haggling approximates it.
explanationSteps.title: First-Degree

explanationSteps.text: Second-degree discrimination offers different versions at different prices. Customers self-select based on their preferences — like choosing between economy and business class.
explanationSteps.title: Second-Degree

explanationSteps.text: Third-degree discrimination segments customers into groups with different elasticities. Charge more to inelastic groups (business travelers), less to elastic groups (tourists).
explanationSteps.title: Third-Degree

explanationSteps.text: Price elasticity of demand determines pricing power. If demand barely changes with price (inelastic), firms can charge more. If demand is sensitive (elastic), prices must stay low.
explanationSteps.title: Elasticity Connection

userInput.lessonDescription: Understanding how firms use price discrimination to maximize profits by charging different prices to different customer segments

mechanicsSteps.text: To price discriminate, a firm must prevent arbitrage — customers who get the low price reselling to those who'd pay more. Physical services naturally prevent this; digital goods require DRM.
mechanicsSteps.title: Preventing Arbitrage

mechanicsSteps.text: Market segmentation identifies groups with different price sensitivities. Age, location, purchase timing, and usage patterns all signal willingness to pay.
mechanicsSteps.title: Segmentation Signals

mechanicsSteps.text: Menu pricing creates product versions that appeal to different segments. The 'basic' version exists partly to make the 'premium' version look valuable by comparison.
mechanicsSteps.title: Menu Design

mechanicsSteps.text: Dynamic pricing adjusts prices in real-time based on demand signals. High demand triggers price increases; low demand triggers discounts. Algorithms optimize continuously.
mechanicsSteps.title: Dynamic Adjustment

mechanicsSteps.text: Bundling combines products to extract more surplus. Cable TV bundles make you pay for channels you don't want because the package captures more total willingness to pay.
mechanicsSteps.title: Bundling Strategy

backgroundSteps.text: No seculo XIX, engenheiros queriam construir maquinas a vapor mais eficientes. Sadi Carnot percebeu que havia um limite fundamental — nenhuma maquina poderia converter todo calor em trabalho.
backgroundSteps.title: O Sonho Impossivel

backgroundSteps.text: Rudolf Clausius e Lord Kelvin formalizaram as leis da termodinamica. Elas explicam por que o cafe esfria, por que precisamos comer, e por que o universo caminha para a desordem.
backgroundSteps.title: As Leis Universais

backgroundSteps.text: A termodinamica e uma das teorias mais robustas da fisica. Einstein disse que, de todas as teorias, ela e a menos provavel de ser derrubada por descobertas futuras.
backgroundSteps.title: Solidez da Teoria

examplesSteps.text: A geladeira e uma bomba de calor que move energia do interior frio para o exterior quente. Isso requer trabalho — por isso ela consome eletricidade continuamente.
examplesSteps.title: A Geladeira

examplesSteps.text: Motores de carro convertem energia quimica do combustivel em movimento. Mas pelo menos 60-70% da energia e perdida como calor — os limites termodinamicos sao implacaveis.
examplesSteps.title: Motores de Combustao

examplesSteps.text: Usinas termeletricas queimam combustivel para gerar vapor que move turbinas. A eficiencia tipica e 30-40% — a maior parte da energia se dissipa no ambiente.
examplesSteps.title: Geracao de Energia

examplesSteps.text: Seu corpo e uma maquina termica. Converte energia dos alimentos em trabalho e calor. Febre significa que o termostato interno foi reconfigurado para uma temperatura mais alta.
examplesSteps.title: O Corpo Humano

explanationSteps.text: A primeira lei diz que energia nao se cria nem se destroi — apenas se transforma. Toda energia que entra em um sistema deve sair ou ser armazenada. E um balanco contabil universal.
explanationSteps.title: Primeira Lei

explanationSteps.text: A segunda lei afirma que processos espontaneos aumentam a entropia total. Calor flui do quente para o frio naturalmente, nunca ao contrario sem trabalho externo.
explanationSteps.title: Segunda Lei

explanationSteps.text: Entropia mede a dispersao de energia entre microestados possiveis. Sistemas evoluem para configuracoes mais provaveis — e configuracoes de alta entropia sao vastamente mais provaveis.
explanationSteps.title: Entropia

explanationSteps.text: Equilibrio termico ocorre quando dois sistemas em contato param de trocar energia liquida. Eles atingem a mesma temperatura, mas nao necessariamente a mesma energia.
explanationSteps.title: Equilibrio Termico

explanationSteps.text: Calor e a transferencia de energia termica entre sistemas. Temperatura mede a energia cinetica media das moleculas. Calor alto com temperatura baixa e possivel (muito material, movimento lento).
explanationSteps.title: Calor vs Temperatura

userInput.lessonDescription: Compreendendo as leis da termodinamica e como elas governam a transferencia de energia e os limites de eficiencia em todos os processos fisicos

mechanicsSteps.text: Em um motor termico, calor flui da fonte quente para a fria. Parte dessa energia e capturada como trabalho. O resto e desperdicado como calor para o ambiente.
mechanicsSteps.title: Ciclo do Motor Termico

mechanicsSteps.text: O ciclo de Carnot define a eficiencia maxima teorica. Depende apenas das temperaturas das fontes quente e fria. Quanto maior a diferenca, maior a eficiencia possivel.
mechanicsSteps.title: Limite de Carnot

mechanicsSteps.text: Bombas de calor invertem o fluxo natural. Usam trabalho para mover calor do frio para o quente — como a geladeira que remove calor do interior e o despeja no ambiente.
mechanicsSteps.title: Bomba de Calor

mechanicsSteps.text: Processos isotermicos mantem temperatura constante. Processos adiabaticos nao trocam calor com o ambiente. Cada tipo segue equacoes especificas de expansao e compressao.
mechanicsSteps.title: Tipos de Processos

mechanicsSteps.text: A conducao, conveccao e radiacao sao os tres mecanismos de transferencia de calor. Cada um domina em situacoes diferentes — metais conduzem, liquidos convectam, o sol irradia.
mechanicsSteps.title: Mecanismos de Transferencia

backgroundSteps.text: Despues de la Segunda Guerra Mundial, el mundo pregunto: como pudo gente ordinaria participar en atrocidades? La psicologia social busco entender el poder de la presion grupal sobre la moral individual.
backgroundSteps.title: La Pregunta Post-Guerra

backgroundSteps.text: Solomon Asch diseno experimentos elegantes en los 1950s. Mostro que personas inteligentes negaban la evidencia de sus propios ojos cuando un grupo unanime decia lo contrario.
backgroundSteps.title: Los Estudios de Asch

backgroundSteps.text: Stanley Milgram llevo esto mas lejos con sus experimentos de obediencia. Revelo que la autoridad percibida podia hacer que personas normales administraran lo que creian eran descargas electricas peligrosas.
backgroundSteps.title: El Shock de Milgram

examplesSteps.text: En reuniones de trabajo, el silencio ante una mala idea se interpreta como acuerdo. La primera persona que habla ancla la discusion, y los demas se conforman por temor a parecer diferentes.
examplesSteps.title: Dinamicas de Reunion

examplesSteps.text: Las redes sociales amplifican la conformidad. Los 'likes' visibles crean cascadas — contenido popular se vuelve mas popular, no necesariamente porque sea mejor, sino porque otros ya lo aprobaron.
examplesSteps.title: Cascadas en Redes

examplesSteps.text: La moda demuestra conformidad en accion. Tendencias se propagan porque vestirse diferente tiene costos sociales. La originalidad tiene limites definidos por el grupo.
examplesSteps.title: Tendencias de Moda

examplesSteps.text: En emergencias medicas, la difusion de responsabilidad hace que nadie actue. Cada persona espera que otro tome la iniciativa, resultando en inaccion colectiva.
examplesSteps.title: Efecto Espectador

explanationSteps.text: La conformidad es el cambio de comportamiento o creencias para coincidir con un grupo. Puede ser externa (actuar igual) o interna (realmente creer lo que el grupo cree).
explanationSteps.title: Definicion de Conformidad

explanationSteps.text: La influencia normativa surge del deseo de aceptacion social. Nos conformamos para evitar rechazo, incluso cuando sabemos que el grupo esta equivocado.
explanationSteps.title: Influencia Normativa

explanationSteps.text: La influencia informacional surge cuando usamos al grupo como fuente de informacion. En situaciones ambiguas, asumimos que otros saben mas que nosotros.
explanationSteps.title: Influencia Informacional

explanationSteps.text: La obediencia es conformidad hacia una autoridad. Difiere de la conformidad horizontal porque hay una jerarquia de poder explicita.
explanationSteps.title: Obediencia a la Autoridad

explanationSteps.text: Las normas descriptivas describen lo que la gente hace. Las normas prescriptivas describen lo que deberia hacer. Ambas influyen el comportamiento de maneras diferentes.
explanationSteps.title: Tipos de Normas

userInput.lessonDescription: Comprendiendo como la presion social y la autoridad influyen en nuestras decisiones, desde situaciones cotidianas hasta dilemas eticos

mechanicsSteps.text: La unanimidad amplifica la conformidad dramaticamente. Un solo disidente reduce la presion a conformarse — no necesitas mayoria, solo alguien que rompa el consenso.
mechanicsSteps.title: El Poder de la Unanimidad

mechanicsSteps.text: La proximidad de la autoridad aumenta la obediencia. En experimentos, la obediencia caia drasticamente cuando el experimentador daba ordenes por telefono en vez de en persona.
mechanicsSteps.title: Proximidad y Autoridad

mechanicsSteps.text: El compromiso gradual atrapa a las personas. Pequenas concesiones llevan a mayores — es mas facil decir 'no' al principio que despues de varios 'si'.
mechanicsSteps.title: Escalada de Compromiso

mechanicsSteps.text: La difusion de responsabilidad ocurre en grupos. Cuando todos son responsables, nadie se siente responsable. Asignar roles especificos contrarresta este efecto.
mechanicsSteps.title: Difusion de Responsabilidad

mechanicsSteps.text: La desindividuacion en grupos reduce la autoconciencia. Anonimato mas excitacion grupal pueden llevar a comportamientos que el individuo solo nunca consideraria.
mechanicsSteps.title: Desindividuacion

While the Anti-Checklist Guidance suggests not heavily penalizing this if understanding is tested, the 'Non-Negotiable Rules' explicitly stated to 'Use novel scenarios' and 'Never test recall of specific examples'. To strictly adhere to the 'Transfer Test' philosophy, the questions relying on scenarios provided in the text (like the organ donation, gym membership, and stock market examples) should be replaced with completely novel contexts (e.g., subscription services, traffic laws, or relationship dynamics). This would ensure learners are applying concepts to new situations rather than recalling familiar examples.

backgroundSteps.text: Classical economics assumed people are rational utility maximizers. But psychologists Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky documented systematic patterns where humans deviate from rationality in predictable ways.
backgroundSteps.title: The Rationality Assumption

backgroundSteps.text: Their research earned Kahneman the 2002 Nobel Prize in Economics — the first psychologist to win it. Behavioral economics was born from this collision of psychology and economic theory.
backgroundSteps.title: A Nobel-Winning Collision

backgroundSteps.text: Richard Thaler expanded these insights into practical applications. His concept of 'nudging' showed how small changes in choice architecture could improve decisions without restricting freedom.
backgroundSteps.title: From Theory to Practice

examplesSteps.text: Investors hold losing stocks too long and sell winners too early. Loss aversion makes the pain of realizing a loss feel worse than the pleasure of locking in a gain.
examplesSteps.title: Investment Behavior

examplesSteps.text: Stores price items at $9.99 instead of $10 because our brains anchor on the left digit. This 'left-digit bias' affects perception more than the actual penny saved.
examplesSteps.title: Pricing Psychology

examplesSteps.text: Gym memberships exploit present bias — we overestimate future motivation when signing up, then fail to attend. The gym profits from our systematic overconfidence about future behavior.
examplesSteps.title: Gym Economics

examplesSteps.text: Default options are powerful. Countries with opt-out organ donation have 90%+ participation; opt-in countries have 15%. Same choice, different framing, vastly different outcomes.
examplesSteps.title: Default Effects

explanationSteps.text: Loss aversion means losses hurt roughly twice as much as equivalent gains feel good. This asymmetry explains why people take irrational risks to avoid losses but not to achieve gains.
explanationSteps.title: Loss Aversion

explanationSteps.text: Anchoring occurs when we rely too heavily on the first piece of information encountered. An arbitrary initial number influences subsequent estimates, even when unrelated to the judgment.
explanationSteps.title: Anchoring Bias

explanationSteps.text: Present bias leads us to overweight immediate rewards compared to future ones. We know we should save for retirement, but the pleasure of spending now feels more real.
explanationSteps.title: Present Bias

explanationSteps.text: Framing effects mean how a choice is presented affects decisions. '90% survival rate' sounds better than '10% mortality rate' — identical information, different emotional response.
explanationSteps.title: Framing Effects

explanationSteps.text: System 1 thinking is fast, automatic, and intuitive. System 2 is slow, deliberate, and analytical. Most decisions use System 1, which is efficient but prone to biases.
explanationSteps.title: Dual Systems

userInput.lessonDescription: Understanding how cognitive biases and heuristics systematically influence economic decisions, and how choice architecture can improve outcomes

mechanicsSteps.text: Heuristics are mental shortcuts that usually work but sometimes fail. Availability heuristic: judging probability by how easily examples come to mind, not actual frequency.
mechanicsSteps.title: Heuristics in Action

mechanicsSteps.text: Choice architecture structures how options are presented. The default, number of options, and order of presentation all influence which option people choose.
mechanicsSteps.title: Choice Architecture

mechanicsSteps.text: Nudges are subtle changes that steer behavior without forbidding options. Putting healthy food at eye level in cafeterias is a nudge — junk food is still available but less convenient.
mechanicsSteps.title: Nudge Mechanics

mechanicsSteps.text: Commitment devices help overcome present bias. Automatic savings deductions work because they make the rational future choice before present bias can override it.
mechanicsSteps.title: Commitment Devices

mechanicsSteps.text: Social proof leverages conformity for behavior change. Telling hotel guests that 'most guests reuse towels' increases reuse more than environmental appeals alone.
mechanicsSteps.title: Social Proof Nudges
